repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Second Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Loan and Assessment of the PSAL Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Programmatic
            Structural Adjustment Loan for Latvia was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was substantial, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned
            from the project: Latvia Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Loan (PSAL) was comprehensive and broad based, but the
            choice of instrument increased flexibility of its
            application. When there is strong commitment by the society
            and the Government, the implementation of reforms does not
            need to be closely tied to the use of resources or to be
            bound by legal obligations. Programmatic operations with
            comprehensive institutional reforms require substantial
            resources for quality supervision. Complementarity of the
            PSAL with investment operations and coordination with
            activities of the other donors are critical for capacity
            building. Interim assessments of programmatic operations
            should either be open to revaluation at the time of the
            program assessment, or there should be an opportunity to
            assess the program as a whole.

Latvia - Second Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Loan and Assessment of the PSAL Program

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Second Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Loan Project, will support Latvia's ongoing
            reform program, to sustain a growth-oriented macroeconomic
            framework, strengthen the public sector's credibility,
            improve institutional capacity in the delivery of public
            services, and, build a transparent relationship with the
            private sector. These objectives will be achieved by
            implementing specific reforms in the areas of fiscal policy,
            public sector management, human resources management, and
            privatization and regulation of public utilities, and
            private business, respectively. Nonetheless, the
            deterioration of the current account deficit remains the
            main macroeconomic risk to sustaining a high growth regime
            in Latvia. Given the currency peg, a shortfall in political
            commitment to fiscal balance, could undermine overall
            sustainability. And, the frequent government changes, which
            have characterized the country since independence, heightens
            the risks to public sector reform, particularly given the
            program's significant emphasis on improved governance.
            To a substantial extent, risks are mitigated by project
            design, and the content of the project as a single tranche
            operation, linked to prior actions. Furthermore,
            Latvia's strong determination to join the European
            Union, also facilitates the continuity of the programmatic
            approach, supported by the structural adjustment program.

Latvia - Second Programmatic Structural
